learning_outcomes.description: Apply fundamental concepts to model, design, and manage organisational data.
Manipulate and retrieve data using SQL.
Develop skills to generate insights from organisational data.
Solve challenges and leverage opportunities in dealing with Big Data.
Collaborate effectively as part of a team to implement data warehousing solutions and generate business insights that enable value creation from data.

assessments.due_date:
Week 2 - Week 10

Quizzes must be completed online within the designated timeframe during the relevant week. More details will be available on Blackboard as the semester begins.
assessments.task_description:
The purpose of this assignment is to test students' ability to use and apply SQL concepts to complete tasks in a real-world scenario. Specifically, this assessment will examine their ability to use SQL Data Manipulation Language to return specific subsets of information that exist in a database.

For this assignment, students will be presented with the simplified schema of an event management application. The goal of the application is to track both the events attended by users and relationships between users and other users. The system is then able to use this data to effectively market recommended events to users based on the events their friends have attended. You will be required to write SQL queries that answer higher-level questions about the data in this database. (Note: Your queries must compile using a MySQL DBMS). A sample database will be provided to help you test your queries.

This will be broken down into 8 quizzes - 1 quiz per week.

AI Statement

Students are permitted to use any form of AI to any degree in completing this assignment. However, they must clearly document any use of AI in each instance. Specifically, students are required to include copies of their interactions with the AI tool as an appendix at the end of their submission. Failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online quizzes will be delivered during Weeks 2 to 10 of the semester and available on the Learn.UQ site for the course.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment has two sections. The first part focuses on modelling a schema and tests students' ability to capture important aspects of multiple systems that need to be stored in a data warehousing database.

AI Statement

Students are permitted to use any form of AI to any degree in completing this assignment. However, they must clearly document any use of AI in each instance. Specifically, students are required to include copies of their interactions with the AI tool as an appendix at the end of their submission. Failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assessment will be submitted within the course's Learn.UQ site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment has two sections. The second part focuses on the implementation of the model designed in part 1, with the students demonstrating the ETL for such a warehousing database covered throughout the semester.

NOTE: Part 2 is a Group Project. An opportunity will be provided to participate in peer assessment of group member contributions to the project.

AI Statement

Students are permitted to use any form of AI to any degree in completing this assignment. However, they must clearly document any use of AI in each instance. Specifically, students are required to include copies of their interactions with the AI tool as an appendix at the end of their submission. Failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assessment will be submitted on the course's Learn.UQ site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Course overview

This topic first introduces relational databases and database management systems. It then introduces conceptual modelling using ER diagram

Live session: This session will focus on staff and student introductions, outlining course objectives, reviewing assessments, and discussing conceptual modelling.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Course overview
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Course overview This topic first introduces relational databases and database management systems. It then introduces conceptual modelling using ER diagram Live session: This session will focus on staff and student introductions, outlining course objectives, reviewing assessments, and discussing conceptual modelling. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Relational Databases and Normalisation

This topic introduces the relational model including its main concept and components, integrity constraints, and how ER diagrams can be mapped into relational models.

Live Session: Entity Relational Diagrams (ERD), Normalisation, and Structured Query Language (SQL) will be introduced.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Relational Databases and Normalisation
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Relational Databases and Normalisation This topic introduces the relational model including its main concept and components, integrity constraints, and how ER diagrams can be mapped into relational models. Live Session: Entity Relational Diagrams (ERD), Normalisation, and Structured Query Language (SQL) will be introduced. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
SQL Bootcamp 1

Tutorial topic: Presents an introduction to relational query language SQL

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 1

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: SQL Bootcamp 1 Tutorial topic : Presents an introduction to relational query language SQL At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 1

learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Introduction to SQL (1)

Structured Query Language (SQL) will be presented in more depth. Different types of data retrieval and manipulation will be explored.

Live Session: This overview of relational database management systems focuses on their core components and functionalities. It then examines conceptual modeling, introducing the widely used Entity-Relationship (ER) diagram, its constraints, and its extension, the Extended ER diagram. Finally, it discusses how design choices inform trade-offs in database design.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 1 : Relational Data Modelling and SQL - Introduction to SQL (1)

Different types of data retrieval and manipulation will be explored. Live Session: This overview of relational database management systems focuses on their core components and functionalities. It then examines conceptual modeling, introducing the widely used Entity-Relationship (ER) diagram, its constraints, and its extension, the Extended ER diagram. Finally, it discusses how design choices inform trade-offs in database design. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
SQL Bootcamp 2

Tutorial topic: This topic focuses on basic SQL queries that use aggregation functions, GROUP BY and HAVING clauses on one or multiple relations.

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 2

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: SQL Bootcamp 2 Tutorial topic: This topic focuses on basic SQL queries that use aggregation functions, GROUP BY and HAVING clauses on one or multiple relations. At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 2

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Introduction to SQL (2)

Structured Query Language (SQL) will be presented in more depth. This topic focuses on advanced SQL queries based on subqueries, division and views.

Live Session: This session introduces the relational data model and its key concepts in database systems. It then examines integrity constraints that ensure data consistency, and concludes with the mapping of ER diagrams to relational schemas.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Introduction to SQL (2)
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Introduction to SQL (2) Structured Query Language (SQL) will be presented in more depth. This topic focuses on advanced SQL queries based on subqueries, division and views. Live Session: This session introduces the relational data model and its key concepts in database systems. It then examines integrity constraints that ensure data consistency, and concludes with the mapping of ER diagrams to relational schemas. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
SQL Bootcamp 3 - genAI Query Writing

Tutorial topic: This tutorial demonstrates how to utilise genAI tools to efficiently generate and refine SQL queries. Building upon your foundational knowledge of SQL, you will learn to write effective prompts to generate SQL code and evaluate the code for accuracy. The session includes illustrative examples to facilitate the integration of AI-assisted query writing.

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 3

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: SQL Bootcamp 3 - genAI Query Writing Tutorial topic: This tutorial demonstrates how to utilise genAI tools to efficiently generate and refine SQL queries. Building upon your foundational knowledge of SQL, you will learn to write effective prompts to generate SQL code and evaluate the code for accuracy. The session includes illustrative examples to facilitate the integration of AI-assisted query writing. At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 3

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Dimension Modelling

This topic focuses on concepts related to data redundancies, data anomalies, data normalization, need for data denormalization, introduction to Data Warehouse, Star Schema, and creation of dimension models.

Live Session: This section introduces the dimensional model, a core design approach in analytical systems and data warehouses. It organises data into fact and dimension tables to support efficient querying, reporting, and multidimensional analysis for decision-making.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Dimension Modelling

Live Session: This section introduces the dimensional model, a core design approach in analytical systems and data warehouses. It organises data into fact and dimension tables to support efficient querying, reporting, and multidimensional analysis for decision-making. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
Dimensional Modelling Practice

Tutorial Topic : Dimensional Modelling Practice

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 4

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Dimensional Modelling Practice Tutorial Topic : Dimensional Modelling Practice At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 4

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Advanced Dimension Modelling

This topics focus on various techniques for creating facts and dimension tables data warehouse architecture, Extract transformation load (ETL), and Microsoft SQL Server integration services (SSIS) tutorial. denormalization, introduction to Data Warehouse, Star Schema, and creation of dimension models.

Live Session: This session explores the role of dimensions in describing and analyzing fact measures within a data warehouse. It covers the structure of dimensional tables—typically wide, flat, and descriptive—and introduces key design techniques, including surrogate keys, calendar dimensions, hierarchies, slowly changing dimensions, and conformed dimensions.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L01

Live Session: This session explores the role of dimensions in describing and analyzing fact measures within a data warehouse. It covers the structure of dimensional tables—typically wide, flat, and descriptive—and introduces key design techniques, including surrogate keys, calendar dimensions, hierarchies, slowly changing dimensions, and conformed dimensions. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
Project Consultation

Project consultation for Part 1 of the Data Warehousing assignment: Dimensional Model Design (worth 30% of the final grade).

Learning outcomes: L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Project Consultation Project consultation for Part 1 of the Data Warehousing assignment: Dimensional Model Design (worth 30% of the final grade).

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - ETL and Metadata

This topics focus on various techniques for creating facts and dimension tables data warehouse architecture, Extract transformation load (ETL), and Microsoft SQL Server integration services (SSIS) tutorial. denormalization, introduction to Data Warehouse, Star Schema, and creation of dimension models.

Live Session: This session provides a high-level view of various design choices in creating a data warehouse and walks you through the process of data integration required for creating a data warehouse.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
ETL Bootcamp 1

This tutorial introduces key concepts and techniques used in building data warehouse architectures. Topics include the creation of tables, denormalization, star schema design, and dimensional modeling. The session will also cover the fundamentals of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes.

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 5

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: ETL Bootcamp 1 This tutorial introduces key concepts and techniques used in building data warehouse architectures. Topics include the creation of tables, denormalization, star schema design, and dimensional modeling. The session will also cover the fundamentals of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes. At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 5

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - ETL and Metadata

This topics focus on various techniques for creating facts and dimension tables data warehouse architecture, Extract transformation load (ETL), and Microsoft SQL Server integration services (SSIS) tutorial. denormalization, introduction to Data Warehouse, Star Schema, and creation of dimension models.

Live Session: This session presents a deeper view of critical design decisions in data warehouse development, with a focus on data integration processes. It covers key components such as ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) workflows and the role of metadata in ensuring consistency, traceability, and effective data management.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - ETL and Metadata

Live Session: This session presents a deeper view of critical design decisions in data warehouse development, with a focus on data integration processes. It covers key components such as ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) workflows and the role of metadata in ensuring consistency, traceability, and effective data management. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
ETL Bootcamp 2

In this tutorial, students will explore the foundational elements of data warehousing, with a focus on building and populating dimension tables. The session covers more concepts in denormalization, star schema design, and dimensional modeling. Additional work in ETL process to gain practical experience using Microsoft SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) to implement data workflows.

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 6

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: ETL Bootcamp 2 In this tutorial, students will explore the foundational elements of data warehousing, with a focus on building and populating dimension tables. The session covers more concepts in denormalization, star schema design, and dimensional modeling. Additional work in ETL process to gain practical experience using Microsoft SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) to implement data workflows. At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 6

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Data Warehouse Architecture and ETL

This topic focuses on concepts related to data redundancies, data anomalies, data normalization, need for data denormalization, introduction to Data Warehouse, Star Schema, and creation of dimension models.

Live Session: This session provides a deeper exploration of data warehouse architecture, focusing on design strategies and the end-to-end ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) process. It also examines the role of metadata in supporting data integration, governance, and the overall effectiveness of data warehouse systems.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Data Warehouse Architecture and ETL
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 2 : Data Warehouse and Dimension Modelling - Data Warehouse Architecture and ETL This topic focuses on concepts related to data redundancies, data anomalies, data normalization, need for data denormalization, introduction to Data Warehouse, Star Schema, and creation of dimension models. Live Session: This session provides a deeper exploration of data warehouse architecture, focusing on design strategies and the end-to-end ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) process. It also examines the role of metadata in supporting data integration, governance, and the overall effectiveness of data warehouse systems. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
ETL Bootcamp 3

This tutorial delves deeper into the ETL lifecycle and its role within a data warehouse architecture. Students will examine best practices for designing robust ETL pipelines, including incremental data loads, handling slowly changing dimensions (SCDs), and optimizing performance in fact and dimension table population.

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 7

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: ETL Bootcamp 3 This tutorial delves deeper into the ETL lifecycle and its role within a data warehouse architecture. Students will examine best practices for designing robust ETL pipelines, including incremental data loads, handling slowly changing dimensions (SCDs), and optimizing performance in fact and dimension table population. At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 7

learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 : Data@Scale - NoSQL in Document-Oriented Databases and MongoDB Data Model Design and Implementation

This topic introduces NoSQL as a solution to the challenges of Big Data, focusing on document-oriented databases. It examines when and why NoSQL is preferred over traditional relational databases, and explores MongoDB as a practical example for handling flexible, scalable data models.

Live Session:  NoSQL database, Types of NoSQL, Document-Oriented Databases, MongoDB, MongoDB vs RDBMS, Collection and Data Modelling Strategies and MongoDB Queries

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 3 : Data@Scale - NoSQL in Document-Oriented Databases and MongoDB Data Model Design and Implementation
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3 : Data@Scale - NoSQL in Document-Oriented Databases and MongoDB Data Model Design and Implementation This topic introduces NoSQL as a solution to the challenges of Big Data, focusing on document-oriented databases. It examines when and why NoSQL is preferred over traditional relational databases, and explores MongoDB as a practical example for handling flexible, scalable data models. Live Session :  NoSQL database, Types of NoSQL, Document-Oriented Databases, MongoDB, MongoDB vs RDBMS, Collection and Data Modelling Strategies and MongoDB Queries Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
MongoDB Bootcamp

This session offers a hands-on introduction to NoSQL using MongoDB Atlas. Students will gain practical experience in designing and implementing document-based schemas, querying nested structures, and understanding NoSQL data modelling principles.

At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 8

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: MongoDB Bootcamp This session offers a hands-on introduction to NoSQL using MongoDB Atlas. Students will gain practical experience in designing and implementing document-based schemas, querying nested structures, and understanding NoSQL data modelling principles. At the end of the tutorial will be SQL Quiz 8

learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 : Data@Scale - Big Data

This topic presents an introduction to Big Data including scenarios and discusses the CAP (consistency, availability, and partition) theorem and its implications on the capabilities and limitations of big data systems.

Live Session: Data at Scale, Data Centres, Big Data Applications, Case Study, Real-time Analytics, Distributed Systems,CAP Theorem

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3 : Data@Scale - Big Data This topic presents an introduction to Big Data including scenarios and discusses the CAP (consistency, availability, and partition) theorem and its implications on the capabilities and limitations of big data systems. Live Session : Data at Scale, Data Centres, Big Data Applications, Case Study, Real-time Analytics, Distributed Systems,CAP Theorem Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

learning_activities.topic:
Project work and consultation 1

This group consultation session provides guidance and support for Part 2 of the Data Warehousing Project: Data Warehousing Implementation.

Students will have the opportunity to discuss their approach to data integration, ETL processes, and SQL-based insights with instructors and peers.

This assessment accounts for 50% of your overall grade.

This assessment accounts for 50% of your overall grade.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 : Data@Scale - Data Volume, Streams and Graphs

This topic presents system architectures to process big data including, for example, Map/Reduce and Apache Spark.

Live Session: MapReduce Evolution, Apache Spark, Languages/Interfaces, RDD (Resilient Distributed Dataset), Spark Streaming, DStreams, Window Operations, Spark GraphX

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04

Students will have the opportunity to discuss their approach to data integration, ETL processes, and SQL-based insights with instructors and peers.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 3 : Data@Scale - Revision

This course has covered key concepts in relational databases, data warehousing, and big data technologies. It introduces the relational data model, dimensional modeling, and data warehouse design, including ETL processes and metadata management. Students explore practical tools like Microsoft SSIS and learn about NoSQL databases, focusing on MongoDB. The course also addresses big data challenges, distributed systems, and processing frameworks such as MapReduce and Apache Spark, providing a solid foundation for managing and analyzing data at scale.

Live Session: This session offers a comprehensive review of the essential topics covered throughout the course, including relational database fundamentals, data warehouse and dimensional modeling, ETL processes, metadata management, NoSQL databases, and big data architectures. It aims to consolidate understanding, clarify complex concepts, and prepare participants for future careers in Data Management.

Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3 : Data@Scale - Revision This course has covered key concepts in relational databases, data warehousing, and big data technologies. It introduces the relational data model, dimensional modeling, and data warehouse design, including ETL processes and metadata management. Students explore practical tools like Microsoft SSIS and learn about NoSQL databases, focusing on MongoDB. The course also addresses big data challenges, distributed systems, and processing frameworks such as MapReduce and Apache Spark, providing a solid foundation for managing and analyzing data at scale. Live Session: This session offers a comprehensive review of the essential topics covered throughout the course, including relational database fundamentals, data warehouse and dimensional modeling, ETL processes, metadata management, NoSQL databases, and big data architectures. It aims to consolidate understanding, clarify complex concepts, and prepare participants for future careers in Data Management. Self-Directed Learning: Students need to complete this weeks self-directed material before the live session.
